problem_text: This is a GeomVerse problem. If the adjacent angles BCA and DCB are complementary, the area of the AEFG parallelogram is 24 and the angle CAB is vertical to EAG, compute the degree of the CBA angle. Round computations to 2 decimal places.
code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.patches as patches
import numpy as np

# Coordinates
A = (34.23, 34.23)
B = (34.23, 12140.4)
C = (5021.239999999999, 15237.179999999998)
D = (270.32, 16795.62)
E = (34.23, -6965.77)
F = (-3394.34, -17417.8)
G = (-3394.34, -10417.800000000001)

# Create figure and axis
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8, 16))

# Draw the cyan triangle (A, B, C)
cyan_triangle = patches.Polygon([A, B, C], closed=True, color="cyan", alpha=0.6)
ax.add_patch(cyan_triangle)

# Draw the magenta polygon (A, E, F, G)
magenta_polygon = patches.Polygon([A, E, F, G], closed=True, color="magenta", alpha=0.6)
ax.add_patch(magenta_polygon)

# Draw the line CD
ax.plot([C[0], D[0]], [C[1], D[1]], color="black", alpha=0.6)

# Draw angle markers
def draw_angle_marker(ax, center, p1, p2, radius, angle_text, color="gray", alpha=0.8):
    '''Draws an angle marker and label.'''
    angle1 = np.arctan2(p1[1] - center[1], p1[0] - center[0])
    angle2 = np.arctan2(p2[1] - center[1], p2[0] - center[0])
    
    if angle2 < angle1:
        angle2 += 2 * np.pi

    theta = np.linspace(angle1, angle2, 100)
    x = center[0] + radius * np.cos(theta)
    y = center[1] + radius * np.sin(theta)
    ax.fill(x, y, color=color, alpha=alpha)

    # Add angle text
    mid_angle = (angle1 + angle2) / 2
    text_x = center[0] + (radius + 0.5) * np.cos(mid_angle)
    text_y = center[1] + (radius + 0.5) * np.sin(mid_angle)
    ax.text(text_x, text_y, angle_text, fontsize=14, ha="center", va="center")

# Add angle markers
draw_angle_marker(ax, B, A, C, radius=1, angle_text=r"$?$")
draw_angle_marker(ax, C, D, B, radius=1, angle_text=r"$50^circ$")

# Add labels
ax.text(A[0], A[1], "A", fontsize=16, ha="right", va="top")
ax.text(B[0], B[1], "B", fontsize=16, ha="right", va="bottom")
ax.text(C[0], C[1], "C", fontsize=16, ha="left", va="bottom")
ax.text(D[0], D[1], "D", fontsize=16, ha="left", va="bottom")
ax.text(E[0], E[1], "E", fontsize=16, ha="right", va="top")
ax.text(F[0], F[1], "F", fontsize=16, ha="right", va="top")
ax.text(G[0], G[1], "G", fontsize=16, ha="right", va="top")

# -- LENGTH ANNOTATION -- #
ax.text((A[0] + E[0]) / 2, (A[1] + E[1]) / 2, "7", fontsize=16, ha="right", va="center")
ax.text((E[0] + G[0]) / 2, (E[1] + G[1]) / 2, "11", fontsize=16, ha="center", va="bottom")

# Configure the plot
ax.set_xlim(-9965.77, 10034.23)
ax.set_ylim(-19965.77, 20034.23)
ax.set_aspect("equal")
ax.axis("off")

# Show the plot
plt.show()

ext_info.cot: The sum of the degrees of an angle and its complementary angle is 90. The BCA angle has a complementary angle with degree 50 so the degree of the BCA angle is 90 - 50 = 40. The lengths of the AG and the AE sides of the AEFG parallelogram are 11 and 7 and the area is 24 so the sine of the EAG angle is $\frac{24}{11 * 7} = 0.31$ and so the angle in degrees is $\arcsin(0.31) = 18.06$. The angle CAB is vertical to the angle EAG so the degree of the CAB angle = 18.06. The degrees of the BCA and the CAB angles of the ABC triangle are 40 and 18.06, so the degree of the CBA angle $= 180 - 40 - 18.06 = 121.94$. Therefore the final answer is 121.94.
